instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an A1534 that had water damages, and has been ultra-sonic cleaned in other store.
Now it doesn't power on.

It has 4.98V on charger and pulls 0.02A.

In PPBUS_G3H i have 0V and on F4700 i have 5V.

Can you help me?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Ultrasonic cleaner can make more damage, if not correctly used.
Sweep function is a must, to avoid hot spots in the process.
Check for knocked off components and broken traces.

Be sure no short on any power rail.

Can we know what board do you have?
Is a must when ask for help.

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Sorry, the board is an 820-00045.
I can't see any broken traces, but It seams that i have a missing SW6900, and the U4490.
I have a short in PP3V3R3V0_AON and in E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L i have 0.99 ohm resistance

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
U4700/80 are the first suspects there.
But more chips are connected on 3V3_AON.

Short on  E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L  points more to U4470/90.
Pray that is not U4600...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Hello again.
It seams that the U4600 is shorted. It is the only thing that gets hoted when injected 2.5V with 3A in  3V3_AON (already taked out the  U4700/80 )
Is it possible to replace the U4600?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: Change it with same from donor board...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: OK. I´ve changed the U4600, and reballed the  U4700/80. The shorts are gone ( 3V3_AON  and  E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L ) but still no boot ( It has 4.98V on charger and pulls 0.02 A).

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground ar 3V3_AON; red probe connected to ground and viceversa.

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Hello,
red probe connected to ground  = 0.341V
black probe connected to ground = 0.859V

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Other chips from 3V3_AON can be damaged.
Even there is no short anymore.
0.341 still looks low; U4700 is the first suspect...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: On pad 1of the board, of the U4700 i have 0.339 but all other pins are arround 0.500 / 600. this maybe means that the problem is before the U4700, don't you think? Am i understanding this wrong?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: OK, replaced the U4700 (from donor board) but the behavior is the same (0.320V)

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Still other chip with problems on 3V3_AON.
Try U4780 now...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Hello again,
I've replaced U4780 and now thr  3V3_AON  its also 0.331 in diode reading, but It is pulling 19.5V but only consumes 0.2A on ampmeter

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Diode mode should be higher than 0.400 I think.
Compare with working board.
Seems that still a bad chip on 3V3_AON...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
I don't have any working board. Is there any other way?
On 2 other boards (parts) the value is near the same. In this board, on  3V3_AON i have 3.28V

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
You've got 3V3 after changed U4600.
It was damaged by overvoltage on 3V3_AON.
Something else must be affected, even not shorted to ground.

"U4700 on the 12" A1534 Retina Macbook from the year 2015 is SLG4AP645AV.
This is the most common cause of a 6-400 ohm low value on the PP3V3R3V0_AON power rail."
This is an old note from dukefawks; so even 400 is lower value than normal...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Good morning,

I've replace the U4700 with a new one, but the same result. On U4700 i have, on BBPD_RPD_EN (PIN 17) 3.2V and on BBPD_VCONN_EN 0V, but on BBPD_VCONN1_EN and BBPD_VCONN2_EN  (Pins 5 and 8) i have 0V.

Now i notated that the power cable only works in one position. If if flip the cable, it doesn' t work.

Is this relevant?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
This denotes a problem with CC1/2 lines.
If U4700 is good for sure, then change U7860/65.

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
I've replaced U7860/65 and the behaviour is the same. 
Diode readings on U4700 of pin 10 is 0.530, and on pin 12 it is 0.546.
With power connected i have on pin10 0V and on pin 12 0.850V.

Is this helpless? do you think i should give up on it?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
Is not recommended to waste too much time on A1534 boards anyway.
All of them end with dead CPU.

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
OK, tanks.
Just for future knowleged, is there any way that i can make sure (at least probable) that it has a bad CPU? Can i mesure something to make sure, and avoid all this time and spare components use?

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message:
As I said, this is not an exact science.
Every time you got A1534 in the service, think if worth the time.
You can solve a power problem and customer can come back in few months with dead CPU/SSD, claiming for warranty.
Try to explain him your previous repair has nothing to do with new problem...

threads.title: A1534 no power
threads.message: OK, Thank you
